Questions & Challenges



Everything was clear. I would still like to mess around more with Quarto.

title: Week 1 Notes - Course Introduction
text:
Connections to Policy


This was a building block week, so not much of direct application rather tracking and documentation baseline for setup.

title: Week 1 Notes - Course Introduction
text:
Reflection

Learning how to create a custom repository was both enjoyable and insightful.
It could also serve as a way to share supplementary analyses and to present code in a more public, graphical, and accessible format for non-coding audiences.

title: Week 1 Notes - Course Introduction
text:
Public Sector Data scinece has several considerations different from private sector

Public good, and equity consideration
Needs to be interpretable and not have algorithmic bias

Git is for version control system (VCS)
Github is the cloud computing backend of Git
Github Lingo

Folder -> Repo
Commit -> Post a snapshot
Push means to send files to cloud
Pull downloads the files to local machine

Setting up repositories on
“YAML Ain’t Markup Language”

title: Week 1 Notes - Course Introduction
text:
Coding Techniques

Basics of tidyverse and its accompanying commands of filter(), select(), mutate(), and summarize()
Quarto functions on how to bold, italics, both bold and italics, code list, and strikethrough
Quarto uses — as the header call
“#” are used as the header calls
Tibbles

select() choose columns
filter() choose rows
mutate() create new variables
summarize() calculate statistics
group_by() operate on sub-groups

summarize and group_by tend ot happen together and typically using a pipeline %>%

title: Portfolio Setup Instructions
text:
Welcome to MUSA 5080! This guide will help you set up your personal portfolio repository for the semester.


By the end of this setup, you’ll have: - Your own portfolio repository on GitHub - live website showcasing your work - A place to document your learning journey




This is what you are building: Dr. Delmelle’s sample portfolio




Before starting, make sure you have: - [ ] A GitHub account (create one here if needed) - [ ] Quarto installed on your computer (download here) - [ ] R and RStudio installed





You should already be in your personal repository (created when you accepted the GitHub Classroom assignment). Now let’s personalize it!



Click on the _quarto.yml file
Click the pencil icon (✏️) to edit
Change "Your Name - MUSA 5080 Portfolio" to include your actual name
Example: "Jane Smith - MUSA 5080 Portfolio"
Click “Commit changes” at the bottom





Click on the index.qmd file
Click the pencil icon (✏️) to edit
Update the “About Me” section with your information:

Your name and background
Your email address
Your GitHub username
Why you’re taking this course

Click “Commit changes”





Navigate to the weekly-notes folder
Click on week-01-notes.qmd
Click the pencil icon (✏️) to edit
Fill in your notes from the first class
Click “Commit changes”





This step makes your portfolio visible as a live website!

Go to Settings: Click the “Settings” tab at the top of your repository
Find Pages: Scroll down and click “Pages” in the left sidebar
Configure Source:

Source: Select “Deploy from a branch”
Branch: Select “main”
Folder: Select “/ docs”

Save: Click “Save”
Wait: GitHub will show a message that your site is being built (this takes 1-5 minutes)





Find Your URL: After a few minutes, GitHub will show your website URL at the top of the Pages settings

It will look like: https://yourusername.github.io/repository-name

Visit Your Site: Click the link to see your live portfolio!
Bookmark It: Save this URL - you’ll submit it to Canvas





Copy your live website URL
Go to the Canvas assignment
Submit your URL





If you want to work on your computer and see changes before publishing:


# Replace [your-repo-url] with your actual repository URL
git clone [your-repo-url]
cd [your-repository-name]



# Edit your files using RStudio
# Preview your changes:
quarto render
quarto preview

# When ready, save your changes:
git add .
git commit -m "Update portfolio"
git push
Your live website will automatically update when you push changes!




Each week you’ll: 1. Create a new file: weekly-notes/week-XX-notes.qmd 2. Copy the template from week-01-notes.qmd 3. Fill in your reflections and key concepts 4. Commit and push your changes






Wait longer: GitHub Pages can take up to 10 minutes to build
Check Actions tab: Look for any red X marks indicating build failures
Verify Pages settings: Make sure you selected “main” branch and “/docs” folder





Check permissions: Make sure you’re in YOUR repository, not the template
Sign in: Ensure you’re signed into GitHub





Check YAML syntax: Make sure your _quarto.yml file has proper formatting
Verify file names: Files should end in .qmd not .md
Look at error messages: The Actions tab will show specific error details





Don’t panic! Every change is tracked in Git
See history: Click the “History” button on any file to see previous versions
Revert changes: You can always go back to a previous version






Commit often: Save your work frequently with descriptive commit messages
Use branches: For major changes, create a new branch and merge when ready
Preview locally: Use quarto preview to see changes before publishing
Keep it professional: This portfolio can be shared with future employers!
Document everything: Good documentation is as important as good analysis





Quarto Documentation
GitHub Docs
Markdown Guide
Git Tutorial




During Class: - Raise your hand for immediate help - Work with classmates - collaboration is encouraged for setup!
Outside Class: - Office Hours: Mondays 1:30-3:00 PM - Email: delmelle@design.upenn.edu - GitHub Issues: Create an issue in your repository for technical problems - Canvas Discussion: Post questions others might have too



Before submitting, make sure you’ve: - [ ] Customized _quarto.yml with your name - [ ] Updated index.qmd with your information - [ ] Completed Week 1 notes - [ ] Enabled GitHub Pages - [ ] Verified your website loads correctly - [ ] Submitted your URL to Canvas

Need help? Don’t struggle alone - reach out during office hours (mine + TAs) or in class!

title: Curriculum Vitae: Mohamad Al Abbas
text:
PhD in Demography, University of Pennsylvania, Expected May 2028

MA in International Affairs, Lebanese American University, May 2023
BE in Electrical Engineering, Lebanese American University, August 2019





Teaching Assistant, University of Pennsylvania – Graduate School of Education (2025–present)

Lead lab sessions on STATA for Principles of Monitoring and Evaluation, a graduate-level course

Research Assistant, University of Pennsylvania – PIRE Project (2023–present)

NSF-funded project on environmental degradation and child development

Paper: Born in a Haze (forest fires & health outcomes in Indonesia)

Support PhD students in Sociology and Demography

Conduct workshops on machine learning techniques

Drafted investigation plans, reports, and conducted interviews

Benjamin Franklin Fellowship, University of Pennsylvania (2024–2028)

MEPI – Tomorrow’s Leaders Graduate Fellowship, LAU (2021–2023)

Outstanding Researcher Award, LAU (2021)

Best Presentation Award, ICIET Japan (2022)





Programming: R, Python, Stata, Java, Assembly

Machine Learning: NLP, RL, Neural Networks (CNN & RNN), Decision Trees

Software: Tableau, MATLAB, SPSS, LaTeX

Languages: English (Bilingual), Arabic (Native)

title: MUSA 5080 Portfolio
text:
This portfolio documents my learning journey in Public Policy Analytics (MUSA 5080).


Advanced spatial analysis and data science for urban planning and public policy.




Weekly Notes: My learning reflections and key concepts
Labs: Completed assignments and analyses
Final Project: Capstone modeling challenge




Mohamad Al Abbas was born in Beirut, Lebanon. He holds a Bachelor’s degree in Electrical and Computer Engineering and a Master of Arts in International Affairs. He is currently pursuing a joint PhD in Demography and Sociology, though he identifies more closely as an environmental demographer and sociologist. His research focuses on climate change and population health, particularly among children under five and pregnant women. Mohamad’s most recent work argues that using administrative borders as controls in climate–health research is problematic in low- and middle-income countries. Instead, he suggests that researchers adopt definitions based on environmental rather than political boundaries.
- View my full CV → - View my Publication list →




Email: ma96@upenn.edu
GitHub: @MohamadAlAbbas-PhD




Mohamad is enrolled in this course to gain a stronger understanding of public policy in relation to urban spatial design, as well as to develop a more streamlined and polished pipeline for coding and research article preparation. He hopes to use this repository as a template for sharing code in publications and scholarly work.

title: MUSA 5080 Portfolio
text: Advanced spatial analysis and data science for urban planning and public policy.

title: Mohamad Al Abbas - MUSA 5080 Portfolio
text:
Born in a Haze: Early-life exposure to forest fires and child health in Indonesia

Examines impacts of forest fire–related haze on children’s HAZ/WAZ growth indicators using IFLS data.

Develops clustering algorithms and k-means quintile regression for fire exposure.

Crude Consequences: The Impact of Oil Spills on Child Health and Environmental Vulnerability in Nigeria

Integrates MICS data with daily oil spill trackers.

Explores stratified vulnerability and child health outcomes.

Climate–Health across Biomes: Stratified impacts of precipitation and temperature on children’s health

Multi-country analysis of diarrhea, fever, cough, and WHZ outcomes.

Examines biome interactions with climate anomalies.

Cross-Border Nutritional Vulnerability in Shared Ecologies (India, Bangladesh, Nepal)

DHS-based spatial analysis of child undernutrition near borders.

Tests whether ecological context outweighs political boundaries.

CRAM (Climate-Resilient Access Metric): Healthcare isolation in vulnerable regions

Developing an index to measure resilience of healthcare access to climate shocks.

Focus on flood seasonality and maternal health risks.

Long-Term PM2.5 Exposure and Cardiovascular Disease in Indonesia

Cohort-based study using IFLS (2000–2014).

Models morbidity-adjusted CVD outcomes under cumulative pollution exposure.

Disaster–Health Mediation: Natural disasters as instruments for water contamination

Uses IV regression with MICS surveys to assess diarrheal outcomes.

Explores mediation via healthcare-seeking behaviors and infrastructure.

title: Mohamad Al Abbas - MUSA 5080 Portfolio
text:
In Progress Methodological Work

Multistate Life Table Models

Transition modeling between Healthy–Unhealthy–Dead states in IFLS morbidity data.

Replication of Payne et al. (2013) with microsimulation extensions.

Spatial Climate–Health Pipelines

Dynamic extraction of precipitation/temperature anomalies via CHIRPS/NOAA rasters.

Integrating z-scores and climate windows aligned with DHS/MICS survey interviews.

title: Mohamad Al Abbas - MUSA 5080 Portfolio
text:
Publications

Disparate social impacts by satellite and self-report: Floods in Pernambuco, Brazil — Population & Environment (under review)

Racism, Discrimination, and Scapegoating in the Era of COVID-19 — IMS Policy and Working Paper Series
Environmental Determinants of Migration: Air Pollution in Developing Nations — IMS Blog – Borders and Limitations (2022)

Gender Inequity in Engineering Higher Education: A Case Study of an American University in a Middle Eastern Country — ICIET Conference Proceedings (2022)

The Impact of Faculty Scholarly Collaborations with Non-Doctoral Students — IEEE IRTM Conference (2022)

The Lebanese Diaspora: From Passive to Retaliatory — IMS Blog – Borders and Limitations (2022)

Quantifying Publisher’s Competence Through Scholarly Engagement — Publishing Research Quarterly (2021)

A Case Study of Gender Diversity in a Middle Eastern University — IEEE IT-Based Higher Education & Training Conference (2021)

Setting the Boundaries of COVID-19 Lockdown Relaxation Measures — Library Hi Tech (2021)

Sustainable Gender Equity Influenced by an Americanized Lebanese Pedagogy — World Conference on Women’s Studies (2021)

Toward an Improvement of Engineering Teaming Skills Through an In-House Professionalism Course — IEEE Transactions on Education (2020)
